You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 464, 808, 479]]<|/det|> - Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page. - Write your answer to each question in the space provided. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 497, 479, 512]]<|/det|> - Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid. - Do not write on any bar codes. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 526, 314, 541]]<|/det|> - You may use a calculator. - You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 589, 214, 602]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 605, 388, 620]]<|/det|> - The total mark for this paper is 40. - The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 74, 465, 91]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 598, 91]]<|/det|> 2 A student investigates the cooling of hot water in a beaker. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 103, 410, 120]]<|/det|> The apparatus is shown in Fig. 2.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[270, 123, 730, 269]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[466, 283, 532, 300]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 312, 918, 330]]<|/det|> (a) The student uses a thermometer to measure room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\). Room temperature is \(22^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 357, 493, 376]]<|/det|> On Fig. 2.2, show clearly the reading \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\). <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 394, 847, 446]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[466, 468, 535, 485]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 511, 921, 528]]<|/det|> (b) The student pours \(100 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\) of hot water into an empty beaker. She records the temperature \(\theta\) of the hot water in the \(V=100 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\) row of Table 2.1, as shown. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 554, 918, 571]]<|/det|> Without delay, she pours \(20 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\) of cold water into the beaker. She stirs the water and measures the temperature of the mixture of hot and cold water. She repeats the procedure <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 587, 695, 604]]<|/det|> until she has added a total of \(100 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\) of cold water to the beaker. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 616, 842, 633]]<|/det|> All the readings are shown in Table 2.1. \(V\) is the total volume of water in the beaker. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 644, 521, 661]]<|/det|> Complete the column headings in Table 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 673, 540, 688]]<|/det|> <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[353, 700, 645, 938]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
(c) Plot a graph of temperature \(\theta(\) y-axis) against total volume of water \(V(x\)-axis). You do not need to start the axes at the origin \((0,0)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 121, 350, 136]]<|/det|>
Draw the best-fit curve.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 166, 788, 572]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 620, 918, 637]]<|/det|>
(d) In the experiment, the student aims to investigate the effect on the temperature of the hot water as cold water is added.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 667, 918, 683]]<|/det|>
(i) Complete the sentence to explain why it is important to add the cold water without delay at each stage.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 712, 543, 729]]<|/det|>
The cold water is added without delay

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[152, 806, 854, 823]]<|/det|>
(ii) Complete the sentence to explain the reason for stirring the water at each stage.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 835, 693, 852]]<|/det|>
The student stirs the water before recording the temperature

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
(e) Suggest two ways to minimise the loss of thermal energy from the beaker during the experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 119, 174, 136]]<|/det|>
1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 179, 174, 197]]<|/det|>
2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 259, 774, 276]]<|/det|>
(f) Name the apparatus that the student uses to measure the volume of water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 535, 91]]<|/det|>
3 A student investigates reflections in a plane mirror.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 103, 430, 120]]<|/det|>
A ray-trace sheet is shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 131, 832, 774]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[466, 841, 532, 858]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 870, 918, 886]]<|/det|>
(a) - Draw a normal to the line \(\overrightarrow{M R}\) that passes through the centre of \(\overrightarrow{M R}\). Label the normal NL . - Label the point at which NL crosses \(\overrightarrow{M R}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{B}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 900, 918, 915]]<|/det|>
- Draw a line 10.0 cm long from \(\mathbf{B}\) at an angle of incidence \(i=40^{\circ}\) to the normal below MR and to the left of the normal. Label the end of this line \(\mathbf{A}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 779, 91]]<|/det|>
(b) The student places the reflecting face of the mirror vertically on the line MR .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 105, 511, 122]]<|/det|>
He places two pins, \(\mathrm{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{2}\), on line \(\mathbf{A B}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 135, 918, 152]]<|/det|>
Mark the positions of \(\mathrm{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{2}\) with crosses (X) on line \(\mathbf{A B}\) at a suitable distance apart for this type of ray-trace experiment. Label the positions of \(\mathrm{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 181, 918, 198]]<|/det|>
(c) The student views the images of pins \(\mathrm{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{2}\) from the direction indicated by the eye in Fig. 3.1. He places two pins, \(\mathrm{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{4}\), so that pins \(\mathrm{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{4}\) and the images of \(\mathrm{P}_{2}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 213, 889, 230]]<|/det|>
all appear exactly one behind the other. The positions of \(\mathrm{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{4}\) are shown on Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 240, 889, 259]]<|/det|>
(i) Draw a line through the positions of \(\mathrm{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{4}\). Continue the line until it meets MR .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 273, 918, 289]]<|/det|>
(ii) Measure the acute angle \(\alpha\) between this line and the horizontal line MR . An acute angle is an angle less than \(90^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[552, 316, 588, 333]]<|/det|>
\[
\alpha=
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 343, 921, 362]]<|/det|>
(d) The student turns the mirror through \(180^{\circ}\). He draws a new incident ray at an angle of incidence \(i=50^{\circ}\) to the normal above MR and to the left of the normal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 388, 918, 407]]<|/det|>
He labels the end of this line \(\mathbf{C}\). This line is not shown on Fig. 3.1. You may draw the line on Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 433, 918, 450]]<|/det|>
He places two pins on the line CB and views the images of the two pins from near the top right-hand corner of the ray-trace sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 478, 918, 495]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 3.1, draw a reflected ray 10.0 cm long from B with an angle of reflection \(\beta\) equal to the angle of incidence. Label the end of the line D .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 536, 879, 554]]<|/det|>
(e) Suggest a relationship between \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\). Justify your answer by reference to the results.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 564, 256, 583]]<|/det|>
relationship

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 595, 257, 612]]<|/det|>
justification

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 695, 912, 713]]<|/det|>
(f) State two techniques that you use in this type of experiment to obtain an accurate ray trace.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 724, 179, 743]]<|/det|>
1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[891, 726, 919, 745]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 846, 91]]<|/det|>
4 A student investigates the relationship between the diameter and the resistance of wires.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 105, 421, 122]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 136, 399, 151]]<|/det|>
- wires with different diameters - instrument for measuring the diameter of a wire

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 166, 245, 179]]<|/det|>
- metre ruler - ammeter

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 199, 239, 212]]<|/det|>
- voltmeter - power supply.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 244, 703, 261]]<|/det|>
Other apparatus normally found in a school laboratory is also available.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 275, 794, 292]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate how the diameter of a wire affects its resistance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 297, 918, 327]]<|/det|>
Resistance \(R\) is given by the equation \(R=\frac{V}{I}\), where \(V\) is the potential difference (p.d.) across the wire and \(I\) is the current in the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 351, 535, 368]]<|/det|>
You do not need to write about safety precautions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 382, 225, 399]]<|/det|>
In your plan:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 413, 565, 430]]<|/det|>
- draw a circuit diagram to show the circuit you use - explain briefly how to do the investigation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 445, 487, 462]]<|/det|>
- state one key variable to keep constant - draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to display the readings (you are not required to

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 474, 416, 493]]<|/det|>
enter any readings in the table) - explain how to use your results to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[436, 74, 562, 89]]<|/det|>
